summary: This document consists of multiple pages of 30-minute check sheets from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York Special Housing Unit, dated July 30-31, 2019. The sheets are used to log staff observations of inmates in continuous locked-down status, requiring checks at least twice per hour. The document is significant as it represents the type of institutional record-keeping in place at the facility where Jeffrey Epstein was held prior to his death. This document consists of multiple pages of 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated July 31 and August 1, 2019. The sheets record staff observations of inmates in locked-down status, with signatures for each time slot, reviewed by lieutenants and a captain. It is a procedural log documenting inmate monitoring protocols. This document consists of multiple 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York for August 1-2, 2019. It records staff signatures confirming visual checks of inmates in continuous locked-down status, such as administrative detention or disciplinary segregation, following a strict observation protocol. This document is a set of 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York for the date August 3, 2019. It records staff signatures confirming visual checks of inmates in a continuous locked-down status, following a protocol requiring observation at least twice per hour. The document is significant as it pertains to the detention conditions and monitoring protocols at the facility where Jeffrey Epstein was held prior to his death. This document consists of 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York for August 4-5, 2019. The logs show staff signatures for regular inmate observations, documenting compliance with protocols for monitoring inmates in locked-down status. This document consists of 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York for August 5-6, 2019. The logs show staff signatures for regular inmate observations, which are standard procedure for inmates in locked-down status. The dates coincide with Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration prior to his death. This document consists of multiple pages of 30-minute check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated August 6-7, 2019. The sheets record staff checks on inmates in continuous lockdown status, with signatures for each time slot. The document is significant as it likely pertains to the monitoring of Jeffrey Epstein during his incarceration prior to his death. This document consists of multiple 30-minute inmate observation check sheets from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, dated August 7-8, 2019. The sheets record staff checks of inmates in locked-down status, with signatures for each half-hour interval. The document is significant as it pertains to the period of Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration prior to his death. This document consists of multiple 30-minute check sheets from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York Special Housing Unit for August 9, 2019. It records staff signatures confirming inmate observations in various tiers (L-Tier, M-Tier, ZA Tier-J, K, G, H, ZB) as per protocol for inmates in locked-down status. The sheets were reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain. This document consists of multiple 30-minute inmate check sheets from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York Special Housing Unit for August 10, 2019. The sheets record staff signatures confirming visual checks of inmates in a continuous locked-down status, such as administrative detention or disciplinary segregation, at least twice per hour. The sheets are reviewed by a Lieutenant and Captain.

persons.name: Operations Lieutenant
persons.context: Staff member responsible for reviewing the inmate check sheets for the Morning Watch shift.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: Senior staff member who reviewed the completed inmate check sheets.

keyFacts: The document is a prison log showing 30-minute observation checks for inmates in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York.
The logs cover the dates July 30 and July 31, 2019, which is the period immediately preceding Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
The procedure requires staff to observe inmates at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule, with all observations to be documented.
The sheets are reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain, indicating a chain of oversight for inmate monitoring.
No specific inmate names are listed on these check sheets; they are administrative forms for recording staff rounds.
The document is a series of prison log sheets showing 30-minute inmate checks in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York.
The logs cover the dates July 31, 2019, and August 1, 2019, which are dates surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration and death.
The sheets document strict observation protocols requiring inmates in locked-down status to be visually checked at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
Each time slot includes spaces for staff signatures, indicating the checks were performed and documented.
The logs were reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain, as noted at the bottom of each page.
The document is a procedural log showing strict inmate observation protocols were in place at MCC New York's Special Housing Unit on August 1-2, 2019.

Inmates in continuous locked-down status (administrative detention or disciplinary segregation) were to be visually observed at least twice per hour, on an irregular schedule no more than 40 minutes apart.
The logs are divided into three watches (Morning, Day, Evening), each overseen by a Lieutenant, with checks reviewed by a Captain.
The document itself contains no named individuals, only staff signature initials and titles (Lieutenant, Captain).

The dates covered (August 1-2, 2019) are immediately prior to Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody on August 10, 2019, making these routine logs potentially relevant to investigations into his detention conditions.
The document is a prison log detailing inmate monitoring procedures for August 3, 2019.
It shows a strict protocol requiring staff to visually observe inmates in locked-down status at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
The checks are documented with staff signatures across multiple tiers (ZA, L, M, ZA-J, ZA-K, ZB) in the Special Housing Unit.
The document is reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain.
This type of log is standard for high-security detention and is relevant to understanding the conditions at MCC New York where Jeffrey Epstein was held.
The logs are from the MCC New York Special Housing Unit (SHU) for August 4-5, 2019, covering multiple tiers (G, H, L, M, J, K, ZB).
The documents show strict adherence to a protocol requiring staff to observe inmates in locked-down status at least twice per hour, on an irregular schedule no more than 40 minutes apart.
Each check sheet is reviewed and signed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain, indicating a chain of oversight.
The logs are routine administrative records from the facility where Jeffrey Epstein was held prior to his death.
No specific inmate names or staff names are legibly recorded in the provided text; the entries consist of time stamps and signatures/initials.
The logs are from the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York for August 5-6, 2019, the period immediately preceding Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.
The documents show strict adherence to a protocol requiring staff to observe inmates in locked-down status at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
No specific inmate names are listed on these check sheets; they only contain staff signatures and time stamps.
The logs were reviewed by an Operations Lieutenant and a Captain for each shift and date.
The document is part of the evidence set (SDNY_00013611 to SDNY_00013617) related to Epstein's incarceration.
The document is a prison log showing 30-minute check sheets for the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC New York.
The dates covered are August 6 and 7, 2019, which is the period during which Jeffrey Epstein was incarcerated there.
The logs show staff signatures for each check, indicating routine monitoring of inmates in continuous lockdown.
The document includes a standard operating procedure requiring inmates to be observed at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
No specific inmate names are listed in the provided text, only staff signatures which are illegible/initialed.
The documents are inmate observation logs from the MCC New York Special Housing Unit (SHU) for August 7-8, 2019.
The logs show a strict protocol requiring staff to observe inmates in locked-down status at least twice per hour, on an irregular schedule.
The dates covered (August 7-8, 2019) are immediately prior to Jeffrey Epstein's death on August 10, 2019, making these records relevant to investigations into the circumstances of his incarceration.
The logs include multiple tiers (J, K, C, H, L), indicating checks were conducted across different sections of the SHU.
All observations were required to be documented and reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain.
The document is a set of prison log sheets from MCC New York's Special Housing Unit dated August 9, 2019.
It details a strict observation protocol requiring inmates in locked-down status to be visually checked at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
The sheets cover multiple tiers (L, M, ZA-J, K, G, H, ZB) within the Special Housing Unit.
Each check sheet contains time slots with staff signatures, indicating the checks were performed.
The logs were reviewed and signed off by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain, confirming procedural compliance.

It details a protocol requiring staff to visually observe inmates in locked-down status at least twice per hour on an irregular schedule.
The sheets contain time slots and staff signatures, but no specific inmate or staff names are legibly recorded in the provided text.
The document is reviewed by a Morning Watch Lieutenant and a Captain, indicating a chain of custody for the monitoring logs.
